sen.j: 郎党（ろうとう、ろうどう）は、中世日本の武士社会における主家の一族や従者。
sen.e: Roto (retainer) or rodo was a family member or a follower of his master's house in the samurai society of the medieval Japan.
Roto (retainer) or rodo was a family member or a follower of his master's house in the samurai society of medieval Japan.
Roto (郎党; retainer) or rodo was a family member or a follower of his master's house in the samurai society of medieval Japan.
sen.cmt: 次文の内容より、漢字表記"郎党"を追加

sen.e: It was also written as 郎等 (roto).
It was also written as 郎等 (roto).
It was also written as 郎等 (roto).

sen.j: 平安時代中期に承平天慶勲功者やその子孫の中から登場した武士階層は、田堵負名、すなわち田地経営者としての側面も持っていた。
sen.e: A class of samurai who had been come from Johei Tengyo kunkosha (people who distinguishingly served in the Johei and Tengyo War) or their descendents was also a Tato-fumyo (cultivator/tax manager), a rice field manager.

A class of samurai who had come from Johei Tengyo kunkosha (people who distinguishably served in the Johei and Tengyo War) or their descendants were also a Tato-fumyo (cultivator/tax manager), a rice field manager.

A class of samurai who had come from Johei Tengyo kunkosha (people who distinguishably served in the Johei and Tengyo War) or their descendants were also a Tato-fumyo (cultivator/tax manager), a rice field manager.

sen.j: 武士たちは在地にあって田地経営を行いながら武芸の鍛錬に励み、国衙から軍事動員が課せられたときは軍事活動に参加した。
sen.e: They worked hard at their training of martial arts while managing rice field, and whenever mobilized for military they participated in the military activities.
They worked hard at their training of martial arts while managing rice field, and whenever mobilized for military they participated in the military activities.

They worked hard at their training of martial arts while managing rice field, and whenever mobilized for military by kokuga (provincial government offices) they participated in the military activities.
sen.cmt: 「国衙から」→訳漏れのため訳出対応しました。

sen.j: こうして彼らは国衙から「国内武士」としての認知を受け、それによって武士身分を獲得していた。
sen.e: Thus, they were acknowledged as local samurai by kokuga (provincial government offices) and thereby obtained their status as a samurai.
Thus, they were acknowledged as local samurai by kokuga (provincial government offices) and thereby obtained their status as a samurai.
Thus, they were acknowledged as local samurai by kokuga and thereby obtained their status as a samurai.
the kokuga forces system
the kokuga forces system
(the kokuga forces system)

sen.j: 上記のような在地武士たちは、戦力を一定以上確保するために、自らに従う者を「郎党」と呼んで主従関係を結んだ。
sen.e: In order to maintain a certain level of fighting power, the above mentioned local samurai established the relation of master to servant with their followers who were called roto.
In order to maintain a certain level of fighting power, the above mentioned local samurai established the relation of master to servant with their followers who were called roto.
In order to maintain a certain level of fighting power, the above mentioned local samurai established the relation of master to servant with their followers who were called roto.

sen.j: 郎党は、武士と同身分であるとは言い切れないものの、在地武士と同様に騎乗する権利を持ち、戦闘に参加する義務を負っていた。
sen.e: Roto could not be declared as the equal status to samurai but had the right to ride a horse like local samurai and the obligation to participate in battles.
Roto could not be declared as having equal status to samurai but had the right to ride a horse like local samurai and the obligation to participate in battles.
Roto could not be declared as having equal status to samurai but had the right to ride a horse like local samurai and the obligation to participate in battles.

sen.j: 郎党の出自を見ると、下人・所従から郎党になった者もいれば、百姓身分の者が在地武士と主従関係を持って郎党となった者もいた。
sen.e: Some roto were originated from lower ranked people or shoju (retainers), and some were from peasant who had formed a relation with local worrier to become a roto.
Some roto originated from lower ranked people or shoju (retainers), and some were peasants who had formed a relation with a local warrior to become a roto.
Some roto originated from lower ranked people or shoju (retainers), and some were peasants who had formed a relation with a local warrior to become a roto.

sen.j: 郎党と同様、武士に従いながら戦闘に参加したのが「家の子」（子弟）である。
sen.e: Like roto, "ienoko" (followers) followed samurai and participated in battles.
Like roto, "ienoko" (followers) followed samurai and participated in battles.
Like roto, 'ienoko' (followers) followed samurai and participated in battles.
sen.cmt: シングルクォーテーションに変更

sen.j: 家の子と郎党の差異は、家の子が武士の一族・子弟であり、血縁関係を有していたのに対し、郎党はそうでなかったという点にある。
sen.e: The difference between the ienoko and the roto was that the ienoko was a family member or a son of samurai and had a blood tie, while roto was not.
The difference between the ienoko and the roto was that the ienoko was a family member or a son of samurai and had a blood tie, while roto was not.
The difference between the ienoko and the roto was that the ienoko was a family member or a son of samurai and had a blood tie, while roto was not.

sen.j: 武士間で主従関係を結んで、ある武士が別の武士の郎党となることもあった。
sen.e: Sometimes a samurai created master to servant relationships among samurai and became another samurai's roto.
Sometimes a samurai created master to servant relationships among samurai and became another samurai's roto.
Sometimes a samurai created master to servant relationships among samurai and became another samurai's roto.

sen.j: 11世紀ごろに武家の棟梁と呼ぶべき指導的な武士（例えば源頼信など）が登場すると、多数の武士が棟梁と主従関係を結んで、棟梁の郎党となっている。
sen.e: Around the eleventh century, as leading samurai like MINAMOTO no Yorinobu who should be called toryo (a leader) appeared, many samurai connected master to servant relationships with toryo and become roto for the toryo.

Around the eleventh century, as leading samurai like MINAMOTO no Yorinobu who should be called toryo (a leader) appeared, many samurai connected master to servant relationships with toryo and become roto for the toryo.

Around the eleventh century, as leading samurai like MINAMOTO no Yorinobu who should be called toryo (a leader) appeared, many samurai connected master to servant relationships with toryo and become roto for the toryo.
